clinical_study.official_title: Relationship of Physical Activity and Diet With Socio-demographic, Environmental, and Metabolic Factors in Arkansas Public School Children

collaborator.agency: USDA Beltsville Human Nutrition Research Center

brief_summary.textblock: This is a cross-sectional study aiming to identify how daily activities affect children's body fitness and general health. Also, the study will address how specific behaviors (such as diet and sleep) as well as neighborhood and home environment affect children's metabolic health and fitness level.

detailed_description.textblock: The purpose of this study is to determine how daily activities, home, neighborhood and school environments affect Arkansas children's health. Children from Central Arkansas ages 7-10 years will be recruited to participate in a variety of physical activity tests including strength, flexibility, balance and endurance. During these tests, participants will perform tasks such as cycling on a stationary bike and extending and flexing their knees on a special type of chair. Body composition will be measured and blood, saliva, urine and stool samples collected. Participants and parents will be asked to complete questionnaires on physical activity, home and neighborhood environment as well as sleeping habits. Finally, participants will wear an accelerometer based monitor that will track their physical activity and sleeping patterns. One in person visit will take place at Arkansas Children's Nutrition Center (Little Rock, AR) and will last around six hours. Reimbursement will be provided.

primary_outcome.measure: Correlation between fitness level and metabolic health
primary_outcome.description: A fitness test will be performed to determine peak oxygen uptake (VO2 peak, ml/kg per min). Correlations between peak VO2 and different markers of cardiometabolic health (IL-6, triglycerides, non-esterified fatty acids, glucose, insulin concentrations, etc.) will be determined. Other indicators of fitness level such as strength, flexibility and balance will be measured and correlations assessed.

secondary_outcome.measure: Correlation between home and neighborhood environments and fitness level
secondary_outcome.description: Home and neighborhood environments will be assessed via interviewer administered questionnaires. Scores obtained from these questionnaires will be correlated with peak oxygen consumption, strength, flexibility and balance scores.

biospec_descr.textblock: Whole blood, serum, stool, saliva, urine

study_pop.textblock: 220 pre-pubertal children ages 7 to 10 years old, both boys and girls, will be recruited from Central Arkansas.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Ages 7 to 10 years
- Boys or girls
- All ethnicities
- All BMIs (all body types)
Exclusion Criteria:
- Severe persistent asthma
- Type 2 diabetes
- Other chronic diseases: lung, heart, liver, autoimmune or endocrine disorders

overall_official.affiliation: Arkansas Children's Nutrition Center and Arkansas Children's Research Institute

patient_data.ipd_description: Individual participant data will not be shared with researchers outside the study.
